data.title: Making dot-completion and object spread operator work together
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1

```ts
let x = { a: 1, b: 2 }
let y = {
  c: { d: 4 },
  ...x // <-- here
}
```

When you actually type the above code, the first `.` you type will trigger completion, showing `c`. If you press the second `.`, it will become `.c.` and should completion of `d`.

To avoid this, you have to press `[esc]` after you type the first `.`.

UPDATE: this occurs with `typescript@2.2.0-dev20161219`, but not in `typescript@2.2.0-dev20161206`.
Seems like a regression.

data.title: [scss] don't offer html tags inside rule sets.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Edit a SCSS file
2. Observe quick suggestions when typing a CSS property

When typing a property in a SCSS file the suggestions shown also include HTML elements like "h1, h2, p" etc. This is not the same behaviour as when editing CSS or LESS files.

**CSS File**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/765486/21336580/5761ef52-c6a1-11e6-9889-3cdec2fa1473.png)

**SCSS File**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/765486/21336629/98327704-c6a1-11e6-8b67-1d2ecab91d4e.png)

Is it possible to prevent this behaviour in SCSS files?

data.title: Find/replace: Keyboard shortcuts for "whole word" and "case" toggles only work in the search field

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Cmd-Alt-W (toggle whole word) and Cmd-Alt-C (toggle case sensitivity) only work in the editor and when the "Find" field has focus. They do not work in the "Replace" input, for example.

Which is annoying when you've typed what to find, have already tabbed to the "Replace" input, realize that the "whole word" toggle is on, and then try to toggle it back with Cmd-Alt-W, which doesn't work.

The keyboard shortcuts should work in _all_ of the panel's inputs.

data.title: Intellisense with TypeScript : too many unrelated suggestions.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. From a first module, export an instance of a TypeScript class which contains getters and methods.
2. Import this instance in another module.
3. Also import 4-5 other unrelated modules.
4. Use a dot to trigger intellisense on the instance from the first module.

Result : too many unrelated suggestions are displayed.

Intellisense doesn't help enough. When using it on the instance of a class, I want to see _the getters and the methods of this instance first_. I don't care about available imports that are unrelated to the object.

For example :
![](http://i.imgur.com/ZcY8k3v.png)

Here, I'd like to see the `dir` and `humanReadableInConsole` getters _first_. Those are defined on the class `configs.logging` is an instance of. In fact, I'd only like to see those! All the other suggestion before those two getters are unrelated to the object.

Is there a configuration to tweak this?

data.title: Map TS  type completion items to CompletionItemKind.class
data.body:
**Bug**
`type` completions currently use the default CompletionItemKind in the completion item provider.

**Fix**
Use `CompletionItemKind.class` instead. This seems to be the best fit for types.

data.title: [Feature Request] SHIFT + SCROLLBAR scrolls all open windows simultaneously in sync with each other
data.body:
Please add the ability to scroll all open code editor windows simultaneously when the user holds the SHIFT KEY and then scrolls the page using the mouse, the mouse scroll wheel, arrow keys or page-up/page-down keys.

Holding SHIFT should synchronize all window scrolling regardless of which code pane scrollbar is selected.

Thank you!

data.title: editor.action.quickFix Only Triggering on First Token of Fix Range
Open In Code - context menu button in Explorer panel
data.body:
It would be very handy to have something like "Open In Code" button in the context menu in the Explorer panel in the VS Code to open selected folder in new instance of VS Code Editor.

_Case:_ When I have VS Code open for a folder that contains many subfolders each of which has another git repository set up and way too many files. I need sometimes open a subfolder quickly in another instance of VS Code for 2 main reasons:
* to have git support for particular repository
* to improve performance by running VS Code on smaller subset of files

I am aware that this could be at the moment accomplished by clicking on "Open In Terminal" button and then typing "code ." However, having a dedicated button "Open In Code" for this would be much better.

data.title: Markdown Preview text color not controlled by styles.css
Adding a property to tasks.json (without warning)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add a custom property to `tasks.json`.

Expected:

Allows custom properties to be set in the file. Custom properties are just ignored by VSC when it consumes/configures the tasks.

Actual:

Complains that the property isn't allowed.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1622880/21331171/be075530-c606-11e6-84b0-99046819badb.PNG)

Questions
1. Is there a schema at play that I can modify on the clients's machine to get rid of the warning?
2. If not, Is there some other way around the warning?
3. If not, any harm in ignoring this warning (i.e., VSC will run just fine and ignore the property)? I'll note it to my extension users in the README then.

data.title: Lingering VS code processes when restarting to update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro, Version 1607, OS Build: 14393.576

Encountered this when updating to version 1.8.1

Lingering VS code processes in the background block it from updating itself

![toomany3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8478946/21331041/89c2b2b2-c60e-11e6-9cb7-27181f0cbe85.PNG)
![toomany2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8478946/21331042/89c2f90c-c60e-11e6-8d3b-838dd489d197.PNG)
![toomany](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8478946/21331043/89cc303a-c60e-11e6-8f72-70fe9d2c1d49.PNG)

The processes you see here are besides the Setup process that was somewhere up the list

I had to manually kill the 6 processes you see here before I was able to update.

data.title: Implement copy and paste of whole files across workspaces
data.body:
Platform: `OSX 10.11.6`
Version of Code: `1.8.1`

Often when I bootstrap new projects, I like to grab existing files like `.eslintrc` and `.gitignore` from other projects. I've noticed that I cannot right-click a file in one workspace, and paste it into a different directory tree in another workspace.

It would be great to have a cut, copy, and pasting of files across the clipboard in a future update. Particularly because getting hidden files to show up in OSX Finder is a pain.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:

- OS Version:Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select two or more lines of text
2. Edit|Replace
3. Type search value into "find" input box
4. Weep as your selection is cleared
5. Explain to boss why you miss deadline because editor hates you

data.title: Default focus to "find" input on execute of replace
data.body: Executing a replace (in file) should set default focus to "find" input field when multiple lines are selected as the find value is not set from the selection and has the value set to the previous find/replace

data.title: Doesn't work ctrl+/
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Settings:
{ "key": "ctrl+/", "command": "editor.action.commentLine", "when": "editorTextFocus" }

Doesn't work ctrl+/. I've reinstalled code, but it doesn't help.

data.title: Enable "find in selection" by default when replace executed against a multi-line selection
data.body:
When doing a replace (in current file) and there is a selection that spans lines, the "find in selection" ought to be enabled by default.

1.  I believe this is standard behavior in most other programmer's editors (visual studio, intellij, textpad++)
2.  Ignoring the current context (multiple line selection) when doing a search makes no sense - why else would the use have made the selection then pressed replace?
3. For me at least, its pretty rare that I want to do a global search/replace.  This is certainly the least likely use case

data.title: Fix TypeScript Verbose Logging not Printing Out Argument Values
data.body:
Fixes #17488

**Bug**
In the calls to `JSON.stringify`, we are currently passing in `[]` as a whitelist. This results in no argument values being printed.

**Fix**
Pass in null instead so that we print all argument values

data.title: Use Module Symbol for TS/JS Module Name Completions
data.body: Adds support for the `external module name` type of completion that typescript returns.

data.title: Allow to dock the panel to the right hand side vertically
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

My monitor is almost twice as wide as it is tall. It'd be really nice to have the option to display the list on the side of the display similar to the way the panels work since the right half of my display is often almost entirely empty.

data.title: Allow access to terminal/process created by debug session launched into internal terminal.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: All

I have run into an issue where when I close a debug session launched in the integrated terminal my code to stop the running process hangs (not a VS Code bug per se). I could ensure that the process gets killed completely if I had access to the process id created during the launch or if I had access to the Terminal created. Providing access to the Terminal (either in the debug adapter or in the associated extension) might be useful for other things as well.
